results.title:
Sequential photographs
Motion Studies: A man standing on his hands from a lying down position
results.credit_line: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy
results.brief_description: British American photographer Eadweard Muybridge laid the foundation of the moving image. Using multiple cameras triggered by trip wires, he captured a galloping horse in sequential images, reproduced them in a zoetrope and created the world’s first moving photographs.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy

results.title: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 6.
results.creator_credit: Don North, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Ian Macleod, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: Peace - is a history of the search for peace throughout the war. The ultimate ceasefire is seen by the U.S. as ‘peace with honour’, and by Saigon as a sellout. “Surrender” - examines the final offensive in 1975, two years after America’s withdrawal. “The Unsung Soldiers” - views the silent homecoming of the veterans. The post war world is unrewarding and sometimes hostile towards men who fought in America’s first ‘defeat’.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Don North, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Ian Macleod, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions

results.title: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 5.
results.creator_credit: Don North, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Ian Macleod, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: Soldiering On - is a study of the morale and battlefield conditions of the American soldier in Vietnam. It also covers the controversy surrounding the American prisoners-of-war. “The Village War” - examines the constant struggle for control of the 16,000 villages in South Vietnam, and the beginning of the ‘Vietnamisation’ process.
results.title_for_label: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 5.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don North, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Ian Macleod, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions

results.title: Winners [Series]
results.brief_description: ‘Winners’ and ‘More Winners’ are anthology series of fourteen telemovies, featuring historical drama, comedy, science fiction, fantasy, adventure and social realism. Each film celebrates individuality and the facing of difficult situations with courage and ingenuity.

results.title: Winners: Top Kid
results.creator_credit: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Gary is a bright boy - a bit too bright for his own good, as the other kids try to prove by beating him up regularly after school. Then he goes on a quiz show and suddenly fame and fortune are within his reach… until they start to rig the show and Gary has to make a very difficult decision.

Cast includes Emil Minty, Harold Hopkins, Michelle Fawdon and Garry McDonald.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Winners: The Paper Boy
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Bob Ellis, Jane Ballantyne, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
During the Depression, Joe’s father gets the sack. The only money the family has is what 13 year old Joe earns from selling papers. Then Joe has a fight with his father and leaves home. He lives on the streets battling with his wits and his fists as he gets to know the characters of the city - the down and outs, the Communist agitators, the Sallies, and Old Harry.

Cast includes Christopher Schlusser, Tony Llewellyn-Jones and Linden Wilkinson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Cox, Bob Ellis, Jane Ballantyne, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Winners: The Other Facts of Life
results.creator_credit: Morris Gleitzman, Esben Storm, Julia Overton, Sandra Levy, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Ben can’t understand how people can live so happily with the injustice and disaster going on in the world. His family’s lack of response leads Ben to mount a one person awareness crusade. Nothing seems to distract Ben from the larger troubles of the world until a crisis causes him to focus his energies on loving and helping his family.

Cast includes Dennis Miller, Anne Grigg, and Ken Talbot.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Morris Gleitzman, Esben Storm, Julia Overton, Sandra Levy, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: The Overlanders [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Dilys Powell, a film critic of the London Sunday Times, analyses the editing of a series of sequences in the Ealing Studio’s 1946 production of “The Overlanders”, directed by Harry Watt. Using the cattle stampede sequences as an example, she shows how the editor obtains his effects by the selection of images and sounds, and points out that the order and length of the shots create a narrative rhythm especially suited to the subject matter of the sequence.
results.description:

results.title: Odd man out: a critique [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Basil Wright analyses Carol Reed’s direction in “The Odd Man Out”. He traces, with the help of blackboard illustrations, the time limits of the story in connection with the movements of Johnny (James Mason), the main character. This main storyline is impinged upon by other characters at various times, the total dramatic impulse being carried forward by these contacts with the hunted man. Mr. Wright then breaks down sequences to scenes, then to shots, underlining his reasons for claiming the title of “masterpiece” for the film. Scenes are shown ‘silent’ and the subsequent showing of a sound version demonstrates the director’s use of unseen factors and sound to lift tension.
